summary: This is an FBI News Briefing dated October 23, 2020, covering a wide range of national security, criminal, and political news. It includes significant reporting on foreign election interference by Russia and Iran, updates on the George Floyd case, the Amy Coney Barrett Supreme Court nomination, and various criminal investigations. The document is a daily intelligence summary for FBI leadership.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Warned about foreign election interference and stated the FBI would not tolerate criminal activity threatening the sanctity of the vote.

persons.name: John Ratcliffe
persons.context: Announced that Russia and Iran had obtained voter registration information and that Iran sent spoofed emails to intimidate voters.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in context of election interference, considering firing FBI Director Wray, and comments on the Affordable Care Act.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Subject of election interference discussions and allegations regarding his son Hunter Biden's business dealings.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: His email story from the New York Post and allegations of overseas business dealings were discussed, with an ex-partner claiming Joe Biden was set to receive a cut.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Commented on election interference, stating Iran is a 'bad actor' but not on par with Russia, and discussed stimulus negotiations.

persons.name: Derek Chauvin
persons.context: Former Minneapolis police officer whose third-degree murder charge in the George Floyd case was dismissed by a judge.

persons.name: George Floyd
persons.context: His death case was updated, with a judge dismissing a third-degree murder charge against officer Derek Chauvin.

persons.name: Amy Coney Barrett
persons.context: Her nomination was advanced by the Senate Judiciary Committee; full Senate vote scheduled.

persons.name: Mark Warner
persons.context: Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chairman who commented on election interference and the Barrett nomination.

persons.name: Marco Rubio
persons.context: Acting Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence who warned foreign adversaries not to meddle in elections.

persons.name: Tony Bobulinski
persons.context: Former Hunter Biden business partner who claimed Joe Biden was set to get a cut of a business deal with China.

persons.name: Lindsey Graham
persons.context: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman who advanced subpoenas for Facebook and Twitter CEOs and the Barrett nomination.

persons.name: Preet Bharara
persons.context: Sued by professional gambler Billy Walters for alleged misconduct in an insider trading case.

persons.name: Billy Walters
persons.context: Sued former U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara and the DOJ, alleging leaks violated his due process rights in an insider trading case.

persons.name: Alexander Hillel Treisman
persons.context: Man arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives who allegedly planned to assassinate Joe Biden.

persons.name: Andy Beshear
persons.context: Called for the release of 'everything' from the Breonna Taylor grand jury proceedings.

persons.name: Stephen Hahn
persons.context: Mentioned in context of FDA approval of remdesivir and reported tensions with HHS Secretary Azar.

persons.name: Alex Azar
persons.context: Dismissed reports of tensions with FDA Commissioner Hahn and commented on new CDC guidelines.

persons.name: James Clapper
persons.context: Commented that foreign actors aim to exploit and amplify divisiveness in the U.S.

persons.name: John Brennan
persons.context: Discussed DNI Ratcliffe's 'credibility' and Trump's relationship with the intelligence community.

persons.name: Rudy Giuliani
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of alleged stolen Hunter Biden emails published by the New York Post.

persons.name: Mike Pompeo
persons.context: Mentioned in contexts of India-US satellite data negotiations, Armenia-Azerbaijan talks, and a Vatican-China agreement.

connections.description: Trump was reportedly considering firing FBI Director Wray after the election, according to administration sources.
Hunter Biden's business dealings and emails were a topic of discussion, with allegations about Joe Biden's involvement.
Bobulinski was a former business partner of Hunter Biden who came forward with claims about Joe Biden's involvement in a deal.
Ratcliffe, as DNI, was reportedly seeking declassification of a Russia inquiry document at Trump's behest.
Walters sued Bharara and the DOJ, alleging misconduct and leaks in his insider trading case.
Chauvin was the officer who pressed his knee on Floyd's neck; charges against him were partially dismissed.
As leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee, they issued a joint statement warning foreign adversaries not to interfere in the election.
As Judiciary Committee Chairman, Graham advanced Barrett's Supreme Court nomination.

events.title: Election Interference Warning
events.description: DNI Ratcliffe and FBI Director Wray warned that Russia and Iran had obtained voter registration information and that Iran sent spoofed emails to intimidate voters.

events.title: George Floyd Case Charge Dismissal
events.description: A Minnesota judge dismissed a third-degree murder charge against former officer Derek Chauvin but upheld other charges in the George Floyd case.

events.title: Senate Judiciary Committee Advances Barrett
events.description: The Senate Judiciary Committee advanced the Supreme Court nomination of Amy Coney Barrett; Democrats boycotted the vote.

events.title: FDA Approves Remdesivir
events.description: The FDA officially approved remdesivir as the first drug to treat COVID-19, having previously authorized it for emergency use.

events.title: Goldman Sachs 1MDB Settlement
events.description: Goldman Sachs admitted to breaking U.S. corruption laws and agreed to pay nearly $3 billion to settle investigations into its dealings with the Malaysian investment fund 1MDB.

events.title: Arrest for Planned Biden Assassination
events.description: A man was arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives; he allegedly planned to assassinate Joe Biden.

events.title: Final Presidential Debate
events.description: The final presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden took place, with clashes over COVID-19 and ethics.

keyFacts: U.S. intelligence officials warned that Russia and Iran had obtained voter registration information and were attempting to interfere in the 2020 election, with Iran sending spoofed emails to intimidate voters.
A Minnesota judge dismissed a third-degree murder charge against former officer Derek Chauvin in the George Floyd case but upheld other charges; the trial is set for March.
The Senate Judiciary Committee advanced the Supreme Court nomination of Amy Coney Barrett, with a full Senate vote scheduled for October 26, just days before the election.
A man was arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives; federal documents alleged he planned to assassinate Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.
The FDA officially approved the antiviral drug remdesivir for the treatment of COVID-19, the first drug to receive full approval for the disease.
